awd_titl_txt: EAPSI: Implementation of Ultra-Fast Control to Advance Benchtop Nonlinear Imaging Systems for Clinical Imaging Viability
awd_abstract_narration:
Second harmonic generation (SHG) imaging, a nonlinear optical process in which photons effectively "combine", is a powerful diagnostic tool for visualizing and quantifying differences in collagen architecture in a wide range of diseases including cancer, fibrosis, connective tissue disorders and cardiovascular disease. Currently, all the imaging hardware and polarization devices of our imaging system are synchronized in an extremely inefficient way. This project takes advantage of profound expertise of field-programmable gate array (FPGA) programming in Professor Shean-Jen Chen?s laboratory at National Cheng Kung University in Tainan, Taiwan. Using FPGA programming, this projects aims for improving the speed and efficiency of the benchtop imaging platform for potential clinical use.

The versatility of SHG imaging is such that it can be coupled with polarization techniques for detecting various collagen isoform distribution indicative of early disease onset. Our current imaging setup operates with the Olympus Fluoview 300 laser-scanning system mounted on an Olympus BX61 upright microscope coupled with various polarization optical components. The system offers precise, motion-free control of excitation polarization using a liquid crystal modulator (LCM) in the infinity space and emission polarization gating using a rotatable Glan-laser polarizer (GLP) on a motorized mount before the photomultiplier tube (PMT) detector. Currently, all of these polarization devices are synchronized using custom LabVIEW programs connected through a National Instruments BNC-2110 connector block that is inefficient and slow. To overcome these issues and progress our system to be more viable for potential endoscopic use, we wish to implement a field-programmable gate array (FPGA) using logic blocks to interconnect our DAQ boards and hardware with much more speed and efficiency. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Ministry of Science and Technology of Taiwan.

por.por_cntn:
Second harmonic generation (SHG) imaging, a nonlinear optical process in which photons effectively “combine”, is a powerful diagnostic tool for visualizing and quantifying differences in collagen architecture in a wide range of diseases including cancer, fibrosis, connective tissue disorders and cardiovascular disease. Currently, all the imaging hardware and polarization devices of our imaging system are synchronized in an extremely inefficient way. This project takes advantage of profound expertise of field-programmable gate array (FPGA) programming in Professor Shean-Jen Chen’s laboratory at National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) in Tainan, Taiwan. Using FPGA programming, this projects aims for improving the speed and efficiency of the benchtop imaging platform for potential clinical use.

The goals of this project was first, to learn the ways of the profound programming expertise of FPGA in Professor Shean-Jen Chen’s laboratory at National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) in Tainan City, Taiwan, and second, to adapt this technology for advancing the speed, reliability, and efficiency of the benchtop imaging platform in the Campagnola Lab at the University of Wisconsin-Madison for potential translation into the clinic.

Indeed, vast knowledge and training of programming FPGAs for controlling polarization optics and laser-scanning microscopes was procured and mastered during advisory time by host Professor Shean-Jen Chen and fellow lab members at NCKU. Specific objectives were met by reducing total image acquisition time by 38% of the specialized polarization imaging techniques developed in the Campagnola Lab. After optimization based on the hardware speed capabilities, a short buffer time, and scanning parameters to match the exact same scan time as before (to make sure laser dwell times matched for comparable signal-to-noise ratios), the total imaging during for this special technique was decreased from 75.6 minutes down to 46.6 minutes. 

The advancement of this system by decreasing the scanning time is just one example of the impact of this newly obtained technological knowledge. We believe that the FPGA programming skills procured from this project will aid in the development of a clinically viable imaging instrument, and if successfully adopted into the diagnostic clinic, could prove to be highly effective in detecting pre-cursor legions in collagen associated with many, many diseases. If this happens, the impact this technology will have on global health will be enormous. This includes, but is not limited to, incorporation of anonymously obtained images in a "Big Data Mine" for machine learning algorithms for bettering pathology, earlier individually prescribed patient care, and "smarter" evaluation of treatments/medications, thus having the potential to save countless lives.
